docs.snippet: The United States has offered Turkey $228 million in aid to seal its agreement to assume command of the international peacekeeping force in Kabul, the Afghan capital, American and Turkish officials said today.    After meeting with Vice President ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The United States has offered Turkey $228 million in aid to seal its agreement to assume command of the international peacekeeping force in Kabul, the Afghan capital, American and Turkish officials said today. After meeting with Vice President Dick Cheney tonight, Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit said the Bush administration had promised the funds to defray Turkey's expenses in Afghanistan and would formally seek approval from Congress this week.
docs.abstract: Vice Pres Dick Cheney offers Turkey $228 million in aid to seal its agreement to assume command of international peacekeeping force in Kabul, Afghan capital; under new arrangement, Turkey would lead force while German colonel would assume second level of command; Britain now commands peacekeeping force in city and is eager to hand over responsibility; US has no interest in command; photo of anti-American protest in Ankara hours before Cheney's arrival (M)

headline.main: U.S. Offers Aid to Turkey To Lead Kabul Peace Force

docs.snippet: The Vatican announced today that it would partly open its prewar archives next year, but would not make available documents on Pius XII's controversial World War II pontificate for at least three more years.    Jewish leaders and scholars expresse...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Vatican announced today that it would partly open its prewar archives next year, but would not make available documents on Pius XII's controversial World War II pontificate for at least three more years. Jewish leaders and scholars expressed considerable disappointment, just as the Vatican itself predicted they would in the announcement. ''We believe that despite the inevitable disappointment of researchers, the Holy Father's decision could provide a solid premise for future studies,'' the announcement read.
docs.abstract: Vatican announces that it will not make available documents on Pope Pius XII's controversial World War II pontificate for at least three more years; Jewish leaders and scholars express disappointment; some scholars theorize that Vatican is trying to get out in front of wave of criticism of Pius XII expected after release of new Costa Gavras film Amen, movie adaption of Rolf Hochhuth's play The Deputy, in which Pius is shown refusing to act on information about Holocaust; Pope John Paul II, only one with authority to open archives, has decided to start with release of selected documents on ties between Vatican and Germany from 1922 to 1939 (M)

headline.main: Vatican to Hold Off Opening Pope Pius XII Wartime Archives

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: NAZI POLICIES TOWARD JEWS AND MINORITIES

docs.snippet: A daylong Security Council session on combating terrorism flared up today when Syria compared Israeli demolition of Palestinian houses in Gaza to the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center.     The Syrian representative, speaking for the first...
docs.lead_paragraph: A daylong Security Council session on combating terrorism flared up today when Syria compared Israeli demolition of Palestinian houses in Gaza to the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center. The Syrian representative, speaking for the first time since his country assumed one of the rotating seats on the 15-member Council, said the body was practicing a double standard in not denouncing Israel's actions against the Palestinians.
docs.abstract: Syrian representative to United Nations compares Israeli demolition of Palestinian houses in Gaza to Sept 11 attacks on World Trade Center; makes charge during daylong Security Council session on combating terrorism; Syria has just assumed one of council's rotating seats (M)

headline.main: Syrian at U.N. Compares Israeli Actions to the Sept. 11 Attack

docs.snippet: President Bush warned today that the standoff between India and Pakistan remained serious and volatile, and he called on Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan's military ruler, to make a clear pledge to crack down on terrorism.    ''I don't believe the situa...
docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush warned today that the standoff between India and Pakistan remained serious and volatile, and he called on Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan's military ruler, to make a clear pledge to crack down on terrorism. ''I don't believe the situation is defused yet, but I do believe there is a way to do so, and we are working hard to convince both the Indians and the Pakis there's a way to deal with their problems without going to war,'' Mr. Bush told reporters at the White House.

headline.main: Bush Seeks Terror Pledge By Pakistan
headline.kicker: THE INDIA-PAKISTAN TENSION: THE WHITE HOUSE

docs.snippet: As the war in Afghanistan nears a possible conclusion, Britain is putting increasing pressure on the United States to follow the fighting with a worldwide antipoverty program unmatched in scale since the rebuilding of Europe after World War II.   ...
docs.lead_paragraph: As the war in Afghanistan nears a possible conclusion, Britain is putting increasing pressure on the United States to follow the fighting with a worldwide antipoverty program unmatched in scale since the rebuilding of Europe after World War II. Gordon Brown, Britain's chancellor of the exchequer, lobbied Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill today to increase spending on antipoverty programs globally by $50 billion annually. Mr. Brown said the increase -- a doubling of all foreign aid -- should underwrite a new Marshall Plan to improve education and health for the world's poorest people.
docs.abstract: Britian presses United States for worldwide antipoverty program unmatched in scale since rebuilding of Europe after World War II; Britain's chancellor of exchequer Gordon Brown lobbies Treasury Sec Paul H O'Neill to increase spending globally by $50 billion annually; says this would underwrite new Marshall Plan to improve education and health for world's poorest people; United States spends much less on development aid as percentage of its total economic output than Japan and European nations do; Bush administration shows no sign of backing large-scale increase in foreign aid generally (M)

headline.main: Britain Urges U.S. to Expand Worldwide Antipoverty Programs

docs.snippet: It may be that when war comes to fashion magazine editors, as it has now and as it did in 1938 to Audrey Withers at British Vogue, the best way for those ladies to stay au courant would be to volunteer as fire-service drivers, transporting soldier...
docs.lead_paragraph: It may be that when war comes to fashion magazine editors, as it has now and as it did in 1938 to Audrey Withers at British Vogue, the best way for those ladies to stay au courant would be to volunteer as fire-service drivers, transporting soldiers. That's exactly what Withers, who died in October, did evenings. And she wore a gas mask doing it, while producing by day a magazine unflinchingly of its time and place. Her ascension to editor in chief was a bit like a game of 10 little Indians; one editor became sick, another returned to America, and there she was with her skeletal staff trying to make fashion make sense in insensible times. Paper shortages meant a subscriber literally had to die before someone else could sign on, and Vogue was only available by subscription. While conceding that ''in those days 'fashion' was an autocratic power,'' she used those powers for good, not evil. The tastemakers of the day worked with the government to trick women into thinking they were choosing certain styles out of desire, not necessity. Short hair wouldn't get caught in the machinery women needed to run; so Withers ran photos of ''the trim heads of the actresses.'' She helped popularize fashion that used as little fabric and labor as possible; moreover, she felt, ''The utility scheme brought anguished cries from some designers, but it did a great service to British fashion, which had been far too elaborate and fussy for its health.'' While she wouldn't have been an ideal peacetime boss lady for Vogue, she made the restrictions of the time seem de rigueur.
docs.abstract: Amy M Spindler tribute to British Vogue editor Audrey Withers, who died in 2001; photo (M)

headline.kicker: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: AUDREY WITHERS, B. 1905

docs.snippet: A United Nations investigator urged a significant expansion of the international security force in Afghanistan, warning that failing to do this could torpedo efforts to create democratic institutions in the war-devastated country.     ''The first ...
docs.lead_paragraph: A United Nations investigator urged a significant expansion of the international security force in Afghanistan, warning that failing to do this could torpedo efforts to create democratic institutions in the war-devastated country. ''The first priority in restoring human rights is security,'' said Kamel Hossain, the United Nations's special representative on human rights in Afghanistan. ''How do you start the rule of law after the rule of the gun for so many years?''
docs.abstract: Kamel Hossain, United Nations's special representative on human rights in Afghanistan, urges significant expansion of international security force there, warning that failing to do this could torpedo efforts to create democratic institutions in war-devastated country; his recommendation runs counter to view of United States and France, which have expressed opposition to expanding 4,800-member International Security Assistance Force (M)

headline.main: U.N. Official Calls for a Much Larger International Force in Afghanistan

docs.snippet: Britain announced today that in response to a request from the United States it was sending 1,700 troops trained in arctic and mountain warfare to Afghanistan to help the Americans flush out remaining Taliban and Al Qaeda fighters.    Defense Secr...
docs.lead_paragraph: Britain announced today that in response to a request from the United States it was sending 1,700 troops trained in arctic and mountain warfare to Afghanistan to help the Americans flush out remaining Taliban and Al Qaeda fighters. Defense Secretary Geoff Hoon told the House of Commons that the battle group, Britain's largest combat deployment since the Persian Gulf war in 1991, would be built around Royal Marine commandos and operate under overall United States command as part of an American brigade.
docs.abstract: British government will send 1,700 troops trained in Arctic and mountain warfare to Afghanistan to help US forces flush out remaining Taliban and Al Qaeda fighters; says move is in response to US request; Defense Sec Geoff Hoon tells House of Commons that battle group, Britain's largest combat deployment since Persian Gulf war in 1991, will be built around Royal Marine commandos and operate under overall US command as part of American brigade; photo (M)

headline.main: Britain Sends 1,700 Troops to Afghan Fight

docs.snippet: President Bush came to Minnesota today to raise political donations  and to promote the benefits of the education bill that he signed into law in January, speaking to students flanked by huge chalkboards displaying the White House-created motto ''...
docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush came to Minnesota today to raise political donations and to promote the benefits of the education bill that he signed into law in January, speaking to students flanked by huge chalkboards displaying the White House-created motto ''A Quality Teacher in Every Classroom.'' More than half of Americans have never heard of the education bill, or its provisions, which forgive student loans to young people who agree to become teachers, polls show. The president's appearance at Eden Prairie High School tried to call attention to the loan benefit and demonstrated Mr. Bush's determination to show that the continuing battle in Afghanistan would not deter him from promoting his domestic agenda or from a $2 million fund-raiser for Minnesota Republicans.
docs.abstract: Pres Bush campaigns in Minnesota to promote his education agenda and to raise funds for Republican candidates; visits high school in Eden Prairie, where he discusses goals in Afghanistan and broader effort against terrorism; campaigns for former St Paul Mayor Norm Coleman, who is running against Sen Paul D Wellstone, Democrat who is one of Senate's most liberal members; photo (M)

headline.main: Bush Promotes His Education Agenda and a Senate Candidate
